prs.truncated_body:
1. `OFTAltCore` rejects transactions where `msg.value > 0`
+ this is because in an `alt variant` we use ERC20 tokens instead of native tokens and you can't pass ERC20 tokens via `msg.value`
+ updates `OFTAltCore` and tests - `MyOFTAlt.t.sol` and `OFTAlt.t.sol` 

2. Caching endpoint's native token:
+ to save gas by reducing a call on every transaction since the token is immutable at the endpoi

prs.title: ethereum: fix tests after forge 1.0 release
prs.truncated_body:
Forge 1.0 changed the meaning of expectRevert, by no longer considering internal calls by default:
https://book.getfoundry.sh/guides/v1.0-migration#expect-revert-cheatcode-disabled-on-internal-calls-by-default

We work around this by overriding the default config in places that rely on this expectation, and simply by invoking external calls in places that just incidentally relied on this.

commits.message:
ethereum: fix tests after forge 1.0 release

Forge 1.0 changed the meaning of expectRevert, by no longer considering
internal calls by default:
https://book.getfoundry.sh/guides/v1.0-migration#expect-revert-cheatcode-disabled-on-internal-calls-by-default

We work around this by overriding the default config in places that rely
on this expectation, and simply by invoking external calls in places
that just incidentally relied on this.

prs.title: Feature/global worker pool
prs.truncated_body:
This pull request introduces several updates to the `substreams` project, focusing on enhancing worker pool management, updating dependencies, and improving the orchestration logic. The key changes include the addition of worker pool factories, the integration of a new worker pool protocol, and updates to the Go module dependencies.

### Worker Pool Enhancements:
* Added `WorkerPoolFactory` to

commits.message:
Refactor worker pooling to support multiple implementations.

Introduced global and simple worker pool strategies, replacing the previous `WorkerFactory` with a `WorkerPool` interface. Updated the scheduler and pipeline logic to integrate the new pools, ensuring better modularity and scalability. Removed outdated tests and adjusted configurations accordingly.
added String() to Unit struct and more println

Add max worker limit per traceID to global worker pool

Introduce a `MaxParallelJobs` parameter to enforce a limit on the number of workers per traceID in the global worker pool.

Fix bug in tick scheduler command
Refactor worker pool client handling and improve logging

Introduce loop.Msg interface and loop.IsMsg struct to prevent confusion in scheduler
Refactor worker pool handling and job scheduling logic
Worker tracking in `GlobalWorkerPool` using a `borrowedWorker` map to manage borrowed workers. Workers are automatically returned when the context is canceled to ensure cleanup.
Update apiKey to apiKeyID and bump worker-pool dependency

Update logging and error handling in worker pools

Replaced userID with apiKeyID in GlobalWorkerPool logging for better traceability. Updated error returned during ramp-up in SimpleWorkerPool to distinguish resource exhaustion scenarios.

Refactor scheduler to simplify delayed job handling

Replaced redundant delay fields and logic with streamlined commands for scheduling delayed jobs.

Handle legacy Tier 1 errors in remote worker setup.

Added a warning log when incoming parameters fail, indicating the issue may originate from a legacy Tier 1. This ensures better debugging while maintaining existing keep-alive behavior for valid cases.
Fix header validation in worker metadata parsing
Fix logical errors in header validation conditions
Enhance logging by adding "keep" field to logger context
Add 'keep' flag to keep-alive log message

Optimize job scheduling by avoiding redundant scheduling commands when `delayedScheduleNextJob` is active.
Use debug level for detailed scheduling logs
Change log level for outgoing headers and update job message
adding retry on fetching worker from redis, if retry fails 3 times, return a free worker

prs.title: fix(kt-devnet): make docker images idempotent
prs.truncated_body:
**Description**

Provenance attestations contain, among other things, a timestamp for the
build, which immediately makes the build non-reproducible.
This in turn creates unnecessary churn for the devnet, as each image
appears different even when it has the exact same content.

Conversely, skipping provenance is not really an issue in a devnet
environment.


<!--
A clear and concise description of

commits.message:
fix(kt-devnet): make docker images idempotent

Provenance attestations contain, among other things, a timestamp for the
build, which immediately makes the build non-reproducible.
This in turn creates unnecessary churn for the devnet, as each image
appears different even when it has the exact same content.

Conversely, skipping provenance is not really an issue in a devnet
environment.

commits.message:
feat(devnet-sdk): first prototype for tx builder

This introduces common interfaces and implementations for building
arbitrary transactions, and processing them.

Going forward, this will be helpful to cover the DSL capabilities
needed to validate tx-centric expectations.

The interfaces are very much a work in progress, but they already have
some nice properties, like the fact that they can be implemented in
isolation (the interfaces manipulate only other interfaces and pure
data objects).

prs.title: util: fine grained deep asan support in spad
prs.truncated_body:
Adds fine-grained deep asan support in spad by making all allocations in spad have a minimum alignment of 8 bytes when DEEPASAN is enabled / a minimum alignment of 4 bytes when MSAN is enabled.

Also note that manual asan poisoning must be on 8-byte aligned addresses, but can be done on arbitrary sizes.

Currently, an MSAN build does not compile... will have to punt this to a later issue.

commits.message: util: fine grained deep asan support in spad

prs.title: Initial groove implementation
prs.truncated_body:
- base: error codes (harmonized with the concurrent data structures), key type (256-bit public keys), memory mapped HPC I/O friendly data block specification (512 byte blocks that are 512 byte aligned).

- meta: concurrent key-metadata store.  This is a thin wrapper around fd_map_slot_para using spatially local key-metadata pairs.  Allows for fast massively parallel testing of account existence

commits.message:
Initial groove implementation

- base: error codes (harmonized with the concurrent data structures),
  key type (256-bit public keys), memory mapped HPC I/O friendly data
  block specification (512 byte blocks that are 512 byte aligned).

- meta: concurrent key-metadata store.  This is a thin wrapper around
  fd_map_slot_para using spatially local key-metadata pairs.  Allows for
  fast massively parallel testing of account existence with details
  about account size and where the account can be found (for latency /
  bandwidth / scheduling purposes).

- volume: This is mostly a thin wrapper around fd_pool_para to provide
  a lock free pool of 1GiB sized volumes that can be stored in a mixture
  of DRAM (preferablly gigabyte page backed), memory mapped 1GiB files
  on NVMe, memory mapped 1 GiB files on SSD, etc.  Some basic operations
  for added and removing volumes from a pool while not stalling or
  otherwise impacting ongoing operations are provided.

- data: concurrent value store.  This is lockfree massively parallel
  allocator similar to fd_alloc but instead of being backed by wksp, it
  is backed by volumes.  Allocator size classes have been tuned for
  account sized allocations and the data block granularity.
  Additionally, the fd_alloc algorithm was tweaked such that parameters
  used for all allocations are discoverable, all allocations can be
  independently tagged (which also means there are non-trivial zero
  sized allocations) and all allocations are independently discoverable.

- top level: Currently just pulls all the above components together.

Also added a thread turnstile primitive to fd_util_base.h (included in
the c.vim syntax highlighter), an API for getting the least signficant
bit from a primitive integer type to fd_bits.h, cleaned up a comment in
fd_bits.h and cleaned up a comment in fd_map_para.c.
